Getting started with NuGet 5.8
NuGet 5.8 is included in Visual Studio 16.8 and .NET 5.0 out of the box. You can also download NuGet 5.8 for Windows, macOS, and Linux as a standalone executable.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Please update latest version to 5.8.0" (#8319) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Please update the `https://dist.nuget.org/win-x86-commandline/latest/nuget.exe` version to 5.8.0 instead of 5.7.0.

There's a problem when using NuGet Restore with 5.7 and MSBuild 16.8 (https://developercommunity.visualstudio.com/content/problem/1248649/error-netsdk1005-assets-file-projectassetsjson-doe.html)

Changing the "latest" version to 5.8.0 would fix many installations using cake-build (Or has @patriksvensson a better solution?).

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "[A11y][ARIA]The purpose of the Learn more link is not descriptive" (#8184) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
Copied from https://devdiv.visualstudio.com/DevDiv/_workitems/edit/1184490
## Browser Details:
Firefox Version: 79.0 (64 bit)

## OS Details

Microsoft Windows 10 Enterprise  ‚Äã

Version 2004 (OS Build 19041.450)


## Repro Steps:

    Hit the URL and login with appropriate credentials
    Tab till "upload tab" item and press enter
    Tab till "Verify" drop down and press enter.
    Tab till "Learn more" link
    Check whether the purpose of the link is defined by the name of the link or not

## Actual Results:

The purpose of the link is not descriptive for the "Learn more" and "Read more" links

   
## Expected Results:
The purpose of the link should be more descriptive. Screen reader should understand it clearly
## User Impact:
Users with visual disabilities may find it difficult to understand the purpose of the link, if link name is not descriptive.

## Notes
Updating the aria-label in this case to a more descriptive text is sufficient. See https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7879 for a similar fix.

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Nuget Package Version History sorting is incorrect for prerelease suffixes" (#8325) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Events.RelatedBody:
### Describe the bug
NuGet Package Version History sorting is incorrect.  It sorted lexicographically rather than understanding the package versioning schema for beta releases.

As an example, RazorLight2.0.0-beta9 comes above RazorLight2.0.0-beta10.

### To Reproduce
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open web browser (mine is Chrome)
2. Go to https://www.nuget.org/packages/RazorLight
3. Expand "Version History" accordion control
4. Observe that it sorts packages by major version number, but when you use prerelease suffixes, the sorting breaks.

### Expected behavior
Why not just sort it by last updated date?

### Screenshots
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/447485/99278405-fde7c980-27fc-11eb-9f09-a391ea63c2b2.png)


### Additional context
https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/nuget/create-packages/prerelease-packages#semantic-versioning implies that `-alpha`, `-beta`, and `-rc` are well known pre-release tags, so it seems natural to expect these pre-release tags to also include version numbers and that these suffix version numbers to sort correctly.

Also, note that for packages like [Newtonsoft.Json](https://www.nuget.org/packages/Newtonsoft.Json/), where the major versions cross from 9 to 10, the major.minor.patch convention sorts correctly, so it seems like the issue is confined to just pre-release tags.  I realize pre-release tags can be any value, but the nuget docs literally suggest sticking with `-alpha`, `-beta`, and `-rc`

Events.RelatedDescription: Closed pull request "scroll ui" (#8322) at NuGet/NuGetGallery
Opened issue "vs2019, when installing some package with NuGet, get the error "you are trying to install this package into a project that targets 'native,Version=v0.0"" (#10298) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
Remove the content above here and fill out details below.

## Details about Problem
I create an empty project. also now there is no network choice when creating a new project in vs 2019

Could not install package AWSSDK.Core  
```
You are trying to install this package into a project 
that targets 'native,Version=v0.0', 
but the package does not contain any assembly references 
or content files 
that are compatible 
with that framework. For more information, 
contact the package author.	
```			
but I set the

```
project property -> configuration properties-> c++/cli  properties 
->.net target framework version : v.50
```


please help me here!

I really appreciate it!

NuGet product used (NuGet.exe | VS UI | Package Manager Console | dotnet.exe):
vs ui NuGet solution
NuGet version (x.x.x.xxx):
unknown
dotnet.exe --version (if appropriate):

VS version (if appropriate):
2019 community
OS version (i.e. win10 v1607 (14393.321)):
win 10
Worked before? If so, with which NuGet version:

## Detailed repro steps so we can see the same problem

1. create an empty project

2. install AWSSDK.Core

...

## Other suggested things

### Verbose Logs

Please include verbose logs (NuGet.exe <COMMAND> -verbosity detailed | dotnet.exe <COMMAND> --verbosity diag | etc...)

### Sample Project

Very helpful if you can zip a project and paste into this issue!

Events.RelatedDescription: Opened issue "VS SDK:  update to 16.9.x" (#10297) at NuGet/Home
Events.RelatedBody:
The following work items are blocked on updating the NuGet.Client solution to VS SDK 16.9.x:

*  https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/9935
*  https://github.com/NuGet/Home/issues/10167

I believe this task is at least partially blocked by [@heng-liu 's task](https://github.com/NuGet/Client.Engineering/issues/367) to update MSBuild dependencies and CI machines to 16.8.x.

Events.RelatedDescription: Reopened issue "November dry run for custom V2 OData query deprecation" (#48) at NuGet/Announcements
Events.RelatedBody:
We announced the deprecation of custom V2 OData queries (https://github.com/NuGet/Announcements/issues/37) last year and we will begin blocking endpoints used by 3rd party clients in **February 2021**. 

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
¬†
There will be two stages in the brown-out to accommodate a variety of usage scenarios. During these times, we will be heavily monitoring social media and other communication channels to address questions and concerns. 
	¬∑ **Nov. 11, 2020** ‚Äì 3 time slots in a 24 hour period, for 4 hours each
	¬∑ **Nov. 17 & 18, 2020**¬† ‚Äì¬†48 hours

Please let us know about your questions or concerns on [this discussion post](https://github.com/NuGet/NuGetGallery/issues/7423).
¬†
Refer to the table below to identify the test slot time in your time zone.
	¬∑ UTC-9 to UTC-2 ‚Äì¬†[Green test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Green+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3923&ah=4)
	¬∑ UTC-1 to UTC+6 ‚Äì¬†[Yellow test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Yellow+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3915&ah=4)
	¬∑ UTC+7 to UTC-10 ‚Äì¬†[Blue test slot](https://www.timeanddate.com/worldclock/fixedtime.html?msg=NuGet.org+OData+deprecation+test+-+Blue+slot&iso=20201111T07&p1=3909&ah=4)

We will conduct **a dry run of the OData deprecation** to ensure that there are no surprises for users, which is scheduled to ensure overlap with normal working hours across the globe. The goal is to help you identify systems that may be affected and will give you an opportunity to take action before we permanently remove support for select v2 endpoints.
